Project Description  The Project is located in Xi’an municipality, the capital of Shaanxi 
Province and a key growth pole in the poor western region of the 
PRC. In Xi’an, the urban population increased from 2.3 million 
(37.3% of total) in 1990 to 3.0 million (42.7%) in 2002. Rapid 
urbanization  in  Xi’an has put pressure on the urban transport 
system, resulting in traffic congestion and increasing motor vehicle 
emission. The Project will support the Government’s development 
strategy by improving the urban transport system by (i) constructing 
an urban ring road; (ii) improving  connector roads; (iii) providing 
urban transport facilities and services; and (iv) providing consulting 
services and training to enhance construction quality, road safety, 
vehicle emission control, and project monitoring and evaluation.  
 
Rationale  Consistent  with  the  Xi’an  master  plan,  large  investments  are 
programmed for road construction, a subway system, and public 
transport operations. Clear and realistic priorities need to be set for 
future  urban  development.  Policy  and  institutional  reforms  are 
needed in urban transport policy and regulations, public transport, 
traffic management and safety, road maintenance, vehicle emission 
control,  driver  education,  urban  poverty  reduction,  and  private 
sector  development.  The  master  plan  gives  priority  to  the 
construction of the third ring road, which will form the main physical 
component  of  the  Project.  Construction  of  a  ring  road  and 
connector roads will provide efficient and safe access within the 
city, and for inbound and outbound traffic. The Project will address 
the  growing  traffic  congestion  caused  by  the  rapid  increase  in 
traffic, inadequate road infrastructure, and poor traffic management. 
The Project has been designed as a public service project because 
people in the urban area will all benefit from the Project directly or 
indirectly through reduced congestion in the urban road network as 
a whole. The project road users, therefore, will not be directly 
charged for its use. Xi’an municipality has identified the Project as a 
priority investment, which will also complement ADB’s assistance in 
developing the Xi’an-Taiyuan section of the national trunk highway 
system. 
 
Objectives   The  principal  objective  of  the  Project is to  promote  economic 
growth in Xi’an by reducing transport costs and relieving transport 
infrastructure  bottlenecks.  The  Project  will  help  develop  an 
efficient, safe, and environmentally sustainable urban transport

system by (i) strengthening institutional capacity through improved 
coordination among municipal government agencies; (ii) improving 
traffic management and safety, (iii)  improving vehicle emission 
control,  and  (iv)  increasing  the  capacity  of  urban  roads.  The 
Project comprises the following components: (i) constructing a 71-
kilometer (km) ring road, including interchanges and bridges; (ii) 
upgrading and constructing 16 km of connector roads to integrate 
the ring road with the overall urban road network; (iii) improving 
five  areas  of  urban  transport—traffic  management  and  safety, 
vehicle emission control, public transport, urban transport planning, 
and  road  maintenance;  (iv)  procuring  equipment  for  road 
maintenance, transport planning modeling, traffic signals and area 
traffic  control  center,  vehicle  emission  inspection,  vehicle axle 
weighing system, compressed natural gas (CNG) filling stations, 
and surveillance and communications; (v) land acquisition and 
resettlement;  and  (vi)  consulting  services  for  construction 
supervision,  urban  transport  component,  monitoring  and 
evaluation, and capacity building.

Risks and Assumptions  The Project has been  formulated to reduce potential technical, 
economic, financial, and social risks. The main potential risks, 
which could result in implementation delays and cost overruns, 
are associated with the  unexplored archeological sites that may

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  (RRP)  on  a 
proposed loan to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Xi’an Urban Transport Project.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  PRC’s rapid economic growth has been accompanied by urbanization, with the urban 
population increasing from 300 million (26.4% of total) in 1990 to 502 million (39.1%) in 2001. 
This urbanization trend is forecast to continue, with the urban population reaching 832 million 
(54.5%) in 2025. Increased incomes and prosperity have made cars affordable to a growing 
segment  of  the  population,  the  emerging  middle  class.  Vehicle  ownership  is  projected  to 
increase from 18 per 1,000 people in 2000 by a factor of more than five in 2020. In  Xi’an 
municipality the urban population increased from 2.3 million (37.3% of total) in 1990 to 3.0 
million (42.7%) in 2002.  This has put  increasing pressure on the urban transport system. 
Between 1990 and 2001, when real economic growth averaged 10.4% per annum, road traffic 
grew at 15.7% per annum for passenger traffic, reaching 4.5 billion passenger-kilometers (km); 
and  10.1%  per  annum  for  freight,  reaching  4.0  billion  ton-km.  Movement  of  goods  and 
passengers will increasingly be by road, as road transport is more flexible and responsive to 
needs in a market economy than other modes. Vehicle ownership in Xi’an grew from 10.1 
vehicles per 1,000 people to 23.1 during the same period. 
 
3.  The road network in Xi’an is underdeveloped in both quality and extent. The total road 
network grew from 2,852 km in 1995 to 3,298 km in 2001, equivalent to an annual increase of 74 
km. The expressway length increased from  16 km to  159 km during the same period. High- 
standard roads, i.e., above class II, account for only  27% of the total road network, and the 
remaining 73% (class III road and below) are medium- to low-grade paved roads and gravel 
roads. Road density relative to the urban area decreased slightly from 5.64 km per square km 
(km2) in 1995 to 5.21 km per km2 in 2000.1 Road density relative to the population increased from 
3.13 square meters (m2) to 3.66 m2 per capita during the same period, which is less than the 
national average of 5.9 m2. 
 
4.  Urban infrastructure  development during the ninth Five-Year Plan (FYP) (1996–2000) 
reflected Xi’an’s commitment to stimulate the economy through public investment.  Government 
investments during this period totaled CNY6.8 billion, or about CNY1.4 billion per year. Because 
of the need to lower transport and logistics costs and remove transport bottlenecks, the road 
sector  received  the  largest  share,  amounting  to  CNY1.9  billion  or  26%.  The  road  sector 
investment grew at an average annual rate of  9.4% during this period, and in 2002 reached 
CNY1.2 billion. The project framework summarizing the main features of the proposed Project is 
in Appendix 1.  An urban transport sector analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
5.  Xi’an is the provincial capital and political, economic, and cultural center  of Shaanxi 
Province.  Xi’an  is  one  of  the  most  important  growth  poles  in  the  western  region.  Xi’an 
municipality comprises the city (with eight districts) and five counties, with a total population of 
7.0 million. Xi’an’s gross domestic product (GDP) was CNY82.4 billion in 2002, up by 13.5% 
from 2001. The GDP is expected to grow by 12.4% per year, reaching CNY117 billion by 2005.

The average annual per capita income for urban residents was CNY7,184, slightly less than the 
national average of CNY7,703. For rural residents income per capita was CNY2,641, slightly 
more than the national average of CNY2,476. The income levels are forecast to increase to 
CNY8,864 and CNY3,500, respectively, by 2005.  
 
6.  The city is located at the junction of two major highways and two major railways. Around 
this transport hub, the city has developed into an important industrial and commercial center 
with many high-tech industries, including electronics, machinery, and pharmaceuticals; and 
service sectors, such as information technology, finance, and insurance. The state-level Xi’an 
Economic  Development  Zone  was  established  in  1988  to  attract  foreign  and  domestic 
investment. So far, 20 km2 has been developed at a cost of CNY4.1 billion for infrastructure. 
The 872 enterprises in the zone have a total investment of CNY38 billion. Inadequate road 
infrastructure, however, is a major constraint on investment by the private sector. Many foreign 
companies will not invest in the interior provinces because of weak infrastructure. An ADB- 
supported survey2  of domestic firms in Xi’an cited poor roads as the most serious infrastructure 
constraint. 
 
7.  The present  urban transport ni frastructure and services  cannot meet the increasing 
traffic demand in Xi’an. The incomplete road network, low standard of transport infrastructure, 
low  flow  capacity  at  surface  intersections,  and  slow  vehicle  speeds  contribute  to  traffic 
congestion, traffic accidents, and increased vehicle emissions. The main causes of urban traffic 
congestion are (i) inadequate road infrastructure facilities and services—road density is low and 
capacity has already been reached; (ii) poor management and maintenance of urban roads—
the existing road space is not efficiently used due to inadequate traffic management and road 
maintenance; (iii) poor public transport services—development is hindered by lack of capacity, 
slow  operating  speeds,  and  outdated  equipment  and  management  practices;  and  (iv) 
institutional  weakness—inadequate  coordination  between  multiple  agencies  responsible  for 
urban transport policy, planning, regulations, and operations. The consequent impacts on urban 
traffic  congestion  include  (i)  increased  transport  costs  comprising  vehicle  operating  costs 
(VOCs) and time; (ii) increasing air pollution due to vehicle emissions that pose health threats to 
urban residents; and (iii) increasing number and severity of road accidents due to poor driving 
practices, large traffic volumes, and narrow roads. 
 
8.  A national symposium, jointly sponsored by  ADB3 and the World Bank in Beijing in 
November 1995, discussed the PRC’s urban transport development strategy and developed 
principles,  criteria,  and  actions.4 Five principles  were  formulated  to guide urban transport 
planning and operations: (i) transport is about moving people and goods, not vehicles; (ii) 
transport prices should reflect full social costs; (iii) transport reforms should deepen to follow 
market principles to increase efficiency; (iv) the government’s role should be to guide transport 
development; and (v) the role of the private sector in providing transport services should be 
encouraged. In line with these principles, the following criteria were adopted for urban transport 
policies and plans: environmental sustainability, economic viability, financial affordability, and 
social  acceptability.  Consistent  with  these  principles  and  criteria,  eight  actions  were 
recommended:  (i)  reform  urban  transport  administration,  (ii)  upgrade  the  status  of  traffic 
management, (iii) prepare a strategy to mitigate motor vehicle air and noise pollution, (iv) 
develop policies to manage traffic demand, (v) develop a strategy for mass transit, (vi) reform 
public transport management and operations, (vii) develop a financing strategy for the transport

9.  The development of Xi’an is guided by the Master Plan: 1995-2010, which sets out a 
broad policy on land use and development, and transport infrastructure that will conserve Xi’an’s 
unique character, historical legacy, and environment. The master plan was updated to take into 
account the significant changes forecast for the next decade.  It provides a good basis for 
planning  urban  transport  development,  including  public  transport.  Urbanization  and  rapid 
economic growth are forecast to continue throughout the period. A large increase in office and 
commercial activities is forecast and will be located centrally. To provide  the required space, 
major redevelopment is planned in and adjacent to the city center. In the master plan, the Xi’an 
urban area will be supported by 11 peripheral satellite towns that will be home to Xi’an’s growing 
population, industry relocated from the inner city, and new industrial developments. 
 
10.  For three reasons, good transport planning is central to implementing the master plan. 
First, because the demand for road space is growing much more rapidly than the supply, there 
are prospects for increased levels of traffic congestion that afflict many large Asian cities. Traffic 
congestion has direct adverse impacts on the productivity and economic performance of cities, 
and  the  life  styles  of  urban  residents.  Second,  because  transport  systems  fundamentally 
influence land use, the master plan can only be implemented if it is supported by a transport 
strategy. Traffic congestion is already making  Xi’an’s satellite towns inaccessible and less 
attractive to people currently living in the city center. Adequate transport links to the city center 
are necessary to make these satellite towns viable. Third, because Xi’an is Shaanxi Province’s 
cultural center, great importance is attached to preserving and enhancing the city environment. 
While  measures  are  being  taken  to  address  environmental  concerns  from  industrial  and 
commercial  sources,6 there  is  mounting  evidence  that  increasing  vehicle  emissions  will 
adversely affect the  city’s environment, including the historic core. An appropriate transport 
strategy is necessary to address the situation.

in road infrastructure have a significant impact on poverty reduction, productivity, and growth. 
The link between transport infrastructure and poverty reduction is also supported by studies7 
and evaluation of completed transport projects financed by ADB8 and the World Bank.9 An 
ongoing TA is examining the socioeconomic impact of road investment in the PRC10 while a 
regional TA11 is being implemented to  review the poverty reduction impact of infrastructure

12.  The private sector will be the PRC’s engine of job generation and the main mechanism 
to increase economic productivity—two essential developments needed to reduce poverty.12 
According  to  ADB-supported surveys (footnote 2), one of which was carried out in Xi’an, 
infrastructure constraints are among the impediments faced by domestic private companies 
operating in the PRC. Of the 756 domestic firms interviewed, 21% cited poor roads as a major 
constraint, the second most frequently cited infrastructure constraint after land and buildings. If 
private investment is to be attracted to the poor interior provinces, the enabling framework and 
transport infrastructure, among other things, need to be improved. 
 
13.  The Government is implementing the long-term western region development strategy, a 
key theme of the 10th FYP (2001–2005), to stimulate economic development in the western part 
of the country where poverty incidence is disproportionately high. The strategy aims to reduce 
development disparities between the western region and the coastal region. ADB provided 
technical assistance (TA)13 to help the Government formulate macrolevel policies and sector 
strategies  for  the  long-term  development  of  the  western  region.  Urban  infrastructure 
development, including roads, was identified as a priority area for investment. The proposed 
Project will support the strategy by improving the urban transport system in Xi’an, an important 
growth center in the western region of the PRC. 
 
14.  External assistance to the urban transport sector has come mainly from ADB, the World 
Bank, and the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) (Appendix 3). ADB provided two 
loans totaling $155 million for the urban transport projects in Shanghai in 1991 and 1992. The 
projects supported an urban development process by financing the construction of the Nanpu 
and Yangpu bridges to provide necessary transport capacity across the Huang Pu River.14 Since 
1991, the World Bank has provided $947 million to finance eight urban transport projects. The 
projects supported urban roads, traffic management and safety, public transport, environmental 
management, and policy and institutional development in selected cities.  JBIC has provided 
about ¥72.6 billion to finance urban transport projects in Beijing, Chongqing, Qingdao, and 
Wuhan. The proposed  Project is consistent with ADB’s policy  dialogue. Formulation of the 
Project has been coordinated with the World Bank and JBIC. 
 
C.  Policy Dialogue 
 
15.  The policy dialogue agenda was carefully designed and discussed with the Government, 
focusing on institutional strengthening, traffic management and safety, and vehicle emission 
control. The topics are discussed  in paras.16–18. Details are  in the  analysis of the urban 
transport sector (Appendix 2). 
 
16.  Institutional  Strengthening.  The  urban  transport  system  in  Xi’an  is  under  the 
responsibility  of  multiple  agencies.  Its  elements—formulating  policy,  planning,  design,  and 
managing urban transport infrastructure and services—are fragmented, and coordination across 
agencies is limited. Local technical capacity is limited and unevenly distributed between agencies.

established a leading group to coordinate the preparation and implementation of the Project and 
other urban transport activities in the city. The elading group is chaired  by the mayor and 
comprises 20 senior officials of the municipal and district agencies concerned. The group will be 
maintained  throughout  project  implementation  and  operation,  and  will  significantly  enhance 
interagency coordination. 
 
17.  Traffic Management and Safety. Road traffic management and enforcement fall under 
the responsibility of the Public Security Bureau (PSB). The limited available road space and its 
inefficient use are obvious in Xi’an. Conflict between pedestrians and motorists, inadequate 
parking service, nonmotorized transport (NMT) operations, increased number and severity of 
road  accidents—all  contribute  to  traffic  system  inefficiencies.  Congestion  is  affecting  the 
economic productivity of the urban area through increased travel times, higher VOC, and a high 
accident rate. Public transport efficiency is hindered by slow operating speeds.  The current 
isolated traffic signal regime  covering 138 intersections is out of date. A better area  traffic 
control (ATC) system is needed to optimize the use of the available and potential urban road 
network  and  improve  safety.  An  efficient  traffic  management  scheme  is  also  required  to 
integrate transport modes, NMT, pedestrian movements, public transport, parking services, 
travel demand measures, and priority facilities, particularly at interchanges. A targeted traffic 
enforcement program and an integrated road safety strategy are also required. In light of the 
findings  of  the  recently  completed  ADB-financed  TA15 on  road  safety,  assistance  will  be 
provided to improve traffic management and road safety under the Project. 
 
18.  Vehicle Emission Control. Given the concern about increasing problems with vehicle 
emissions in Asia, ADB has prepared the Policy Guidelines for Reducing Vehicle Emissions in 
Asia.16 In Xi’an, vehicle emissions pose health threats to the urban population.17 Congestion and 
inadequate traffic management make emissions worse. The PSB and Environment Protection 
Bureau (EPB) share responsibility for air quality control, inspection and maintenance, annual 
vehicle testing centers, and enforcement. Conversion to cleaner fuel is in progress; 300 buses 
and 10,000 taxies use compressed natural gas (CNG) in Xi’an. There are only 7 CNG stations, 
but the government plans to build 50 more stations by 2005. Funding limitations and shortages 
of skills and resources are key obstacles to improved vehicle emissions control. Seven vehicle 
testing centers, operated by the PSB with support from the EPB, inspect safety aspects and 
emission standards. The Xi’an municipal government will strengthen vehicle emission control 
under the Project.

D.  Lessons Learned 
 
19.  Lessons learned from the ADB-financed urban transport projects18 suggest that it is not 
cost-effective to charge tolls on urban ring roads and bridges because long lines waiting to pay 
the tolls would spill over into the connector roads causing traffic congestion. The project cost was, 
therefore, recovered from municipal road user charges. Other lessons include (i) the benefits of a 
comprehensive and participatory approach to project preparation, (ii) the benefits of a planned 
and  well-coordinated  resettlement  scheme  preceded  by  adequate  consultation  with  affected 
parties before relocation, and (iii) the need for a professional approach to forecasting traffic 
demand. While these projects were successful, their development impact would have been 
greater if more attention had been paid to issues like traffic management, vehicle emissions, and 
public transport. Their experience demonstrates that the provision of urban infrastructure can 
have a profound impact on urban land use. Lessons learned from other externally financed urban 
transport projects19 in the PRC include the following: (i) coordination among agencies concerned 
with urban transport planning and implementation needs to be improved; (ii) participation of all 
agencies  with  responsibilities  for  urban  transport  is  key  to  developing  an  integrated  and 
sustainable project; and (iii) investment in urban roads needs to be complemented by improving 
other urban transport aspects, such as traffic management and safety, vehicle emission control, 
and road maintenance. These lessons are incorporated in the project design.

loans to the road sector in the PRC have been or are being  implemented satisfactorily. The 
project completion reports (PCRs) prepared for nine road projects conclude that six projects21

E.  Rationale 
 
21.  The overall  objective of the country strategy and program24 is to promote pro-poor 
economic growth by giving the poor greater access to opportunities and benefits of economic 
prosperity. The strategy is designed to (i) promote equitable and inclusive growth, (ii) make 
markets work more effectively, (iii) protect the environment, and (iv) promote cooperation with 
neighboring countries. An essential thrust of the strategy is to increase assistance to the poor 
central and western provinces, including Shaanxi Province, by supporting projects that facilitate 
pro-poor economic growth. In the transport sector, the strategy will help remove transport 
infrastructure  constraints  and  improve  the  urban  environment.  An  efficient,  safe,  and 
environmentally sustainable transport network is needed to promote economic growth and 
benefit the poor in urban and rural areas. Urban infrastructure, such as road transport systems 
and public utilities, will need to be improved to cope with the increasing burden as a result of 
rapid  urbanization.  The  proposed  Project,  designed  to  remove  transport  bottlenecks  and 
address environmental concerns in Xi’an, one of the major growth centers in the western region, 
is consistent with PRC’s development priorities and ADB’s strategy. The proposed Project is 
also consistent with ADB’s urban sector strategy,25 which supports investing in the urban sector 
because of the central role urban centers play in economic growth. Urban areas are dynamic 
engines of growth and employment creation, centers for innovation and entrepreneurship, and 
sources of social services. 
 
22.  Consistent with the Xi’an master plan,  large investments are programmed for road 
construction, a subway system, and public transport operations. Clear and realistic priorities 
need to be set for future urban development.  Policy and institutional reforms  are needed  in 
urban transport policy and regulations, public transport, traffic management and safety, road 
maintenance, vehicle emission control, driver education, urban poverty reduction, and private 
sector development. The  master plan  gives priority to the construction of the third ring road 
(TRR)  shown  in  Map  2,  which  will  form  the  main  physical  component  of  the  Project. 
Construction of a ring road and connector roads will provide efficient and safe access within the 
city,  and  for  inbound  and  outbound  traffic.  The  Project  will  address  the  growing  traffic 
congestion caused by the rapid increase in traffic, inadequate road infrastructure, and poor 
traffic management. The Project has been designed as a public service project because people 
in  the  urban  area  will  all  benefit  from  the  Project  directly  or  indirectly  through  reduced 
congestion in the urban road network as a whole. The project road users, therefore, will not be 
directly charged for its use. Xi’an municipality has identified the Project as a priority investment, 
which will also complement ADB’s assistance in developing the Xi’an-Taiyuan section of the 
national trunk highway system.26

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Objective 
 
24.  The principal objective of the Project is to promote economic growth in Xi’an municipality 
by relieving transport infrastructure bottlenecks. The Project will help develop an efficient, safe, 
and  environmentally  sustainable  urban  transport  system  by  (i)  strengthening  institutional 
capacity through improved coordination among municipal government agencies, (ii) improving 
traffic management and safety, (iii) improving vehicle emission control, and (iv) increasing the 
capacity of urban roads. 
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
 
25.  The Project comprises the following components: (i) constructing a 71 km third ring road 
(TRR),28 including interchanges and bridges; (ii) upgrading and constructing 16 km of connector 
roads to integrate the ring road with the overall urban road network; (iii) improving urban 
transport in four areas: traffic management and safety, vehicle emission control, public transport, 
urban transport planning, and road maintenance; (iv) procuring equipment for road maintenance, 
transport planning modeling, traffic signals and ATC center, vehicle emission inspection, vehicle 
axle weighing system, CNG filling stations, and  surveillance and communications; (v) land 
acquisition and resettlement; and (vi) consulting services for construction supervision, urban 
transport component, monitoring and evaluation, and capacity building. As the project design 
involves integration with the existing provincial road, project preparation is being coordinated by 
the leading group (para.16) with the relevant provincial government authorities. 
 
26.  The urban transport improvement component (Appendix 4) includes (i) an ATC system 
for  traffic  signals,  main  control  center  and  traffic  management  scheme;  (ii)  developing  a 
comprehensive urban transport model, and a bus priority corridor scheme; (iii) a road safety 
strategy and safety audit; (iv) building CNG filling stations, a mobile emission inspection system, 
and formulating an action plan for air quality management and vehicle emissions control; and (v) 
road  maintenance,  maintenance  equipment,  and  developing  an  asset  management  and 
maintenance strategy.

benefits will accrue to the project area.

A.  Traffic Forecasts 
 
47.  Traffic was modeled over the entire affected road network, with and without the Project, 
to determine the impact of the additional road capacity on road user costs in terms of travel 
time, VOCs, and accidents. Vehicle trips were assigned to the Xi’an internal and external road 
network using a matrix of 88 zones within the TRR and 24 zones outside the TRR. The road 
network comprises about 3,000 links in 2008 and 4,850 links in 2028.  Based on the ADB-
financed TA (footnote 27), the forecast traffic volume on the TRR is expected to grow from 
14,500–48,500 passenger car units (pcu) per day in 2008, depending on the link, to 41,700–
72,000 pcu in 2018, equivalent to annual growth rates ranging between 3.5% and 11.7%. Traffic 
will grow more slowly at 4.6%–8.2% per annum thereafter to reach 88,800–146,000 pcu in 2028 
(Appendix 11 and Supplementary Appendix A). The projected volumes can be accommodated 
in the TRR and justify the construction of the Project. 
 
B.  Economic Benefits 
 
48.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated by comparing the with- and 
without-project situations. The Project will provide relief for the increasingly congested central 
area of Xi’an, and the connector roads will improve the distribution of traffic between the second 
ring road and the Project. Access from the poorer outer areas of the municipality and from nine 
satellite towns to Xi’an’s relatively developed central area will improve. The investment will 
facilitate commercial and industrial development in adjacent areas. 
 
49.  The economic costs of the Project reflect the resource costs for construction, operation 
and maintenance (O&M), and the value of agricultural production from land lost permanently. 
The economic benefits include (i) savings in VOCs as a result of improved traffic conditions, (ii) 
passenger time savings, and (iii) savings from avoided physical damage as a result of fewer 
accidents. Environmental benefits will result from avoided vehicular emissions as a result of the 
reduced level of congestion on  the urban road network. However, these benefits were not 
included in the economic analysis because an established methodology for their valuation is not 
available. 
 
50.  The EIRR for the Project is 15.4%, indicating that the Project is economically viable 
(Appendix 12). Results of sensitivity analysis confirm the robustness of the Project's economic 
viability. Changes in the key variables, such as a 20% reduction in benefits, do not significantly 
impact economic viability. The capital cost would have to increase by 44% over the estimate for 
the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. The benefit level would have to decrease by 30% 
to achieve the same effect. In light of previous experience in the PRC road sector, variations of 
such magnitude are unlikely. 
 
C.  Municipal Infrastructure Finance 
 
51.  XMURCC  is  responsible  for  providing  urban  infrastructure  facilities  and  services, 
including urban roads, water supply, city sewage services,  central heating, gas,  wastewater 
treatment, and environmental management and landscaping. The expenditures on the urban 
roads  increased at 35% per annum in the last 5 years and reached CNY1.20 billion, 64% of the 
total urban construction expenditures of CNY1.87 billion in 2002. During the same period, urban 
infrastructure maintenance expenditures increased at 12% per annum and reached CNY230 
million  in  2002.  XMURCC  has  set  a  budget  of  CNY5.54  billion  for  urban  construction 
expenditures in 2003, almost three times the level in 2002. This budget includes CNY3.2 billion 
for road construction, accounting for about 57%. The main revenue sources used to finance 
urban construction are central and provincial government grants (4%); municipal taxes, land

15
transfer fees, and water fees (21%); local policy income  (7%); project financing from other 
sources (19%); self-raised funds (17%); domestic bank loans (27%); and foreign financing (5%). 
Details are in Appendix 13. It is currently proposed that the cost of the Project be recovered 
through these municipal government revenues. XMG will provide sufficient budget from its 
sources to  cover the O&M costs30 and service debt. The EA will review alternative revenue 
sources from the municipal government revenue and submit its proposal to ADB by the time of 
the midterm review of the Project. 
 
D.  Impact on Poverty 
 
52.  Key issues identified in the initial poverty and social assessment undertaken during TA 
fact-finding were assessed in  more detail during the poverty reduction and social analysis 
carried out under the TA (Appendix 14 and Supplementary Appendix B). The key issues related 
to resettlement and impacts on the poor. The broader trends in the project area as well as the 
needs of affected people and their ability to benefit from the Project were also examined. There 
are 3 million people in the project area: 1.9 million in the urban area of Xi’an municipality, and 
1.1 million in  the rural area.  The lower-income vulnerable groups include  4.2% of  the urban 
residents earning less than CNY3,000 per capita per annum and 8.0% of the rural residents 
earning less than CNY1,000 per capita per annum. 
 
53.  The Project will have both direct and indirect impacts on the poor. Direct impacts will be 
through construction employment opportunities, savings in travel time, and the potential for VOC 
savings in public transport for passengers to be passed on to passengers. Indirect benefits will 
be  from  the  urbanization  process  that  will  be  facilitated  by  the  TRR,  which  provides  the 
opportunity for households to diversify and increase employment opportunities and incomes. 
Household poverty and vulnerability will be reduced with multiple income earners per household 
and more than one source of income. Rural households with nonagricultural income are better 
off than households that rely only on farming (cropping or livestock) income. The Project will 
provide indirect benefits through the urbanization process, such as new housing, improved 
access to social services, and employment opportunities. 
 
54.  The Project does not adversely affect or significantly impact the livelihoods of ethnic 
minorities and is gender neutral in adverse impacts and benefits. The Project includes some 
social development actions to enhance benefits for  the poor, women, and vulnerable groups 
(Appendix 14).

G.  Risks 
 
60.  The Project  has been  formulated to reduce potential technical, economic, and social 
risks. The main risks, which could result in implementation delays and cost overruns, are 
associated with the unexplored archeological sites that may be discovered during excavation, 
given the historical nature of the project area. To mitigate the risks, a special advisory team will 
prepare appropriate mitigation measures. XMURCC has proven experience in dealing with this 
kind of situation. Given the magnitude and complexity of land acquisition and displacement of 
houses and enterprises, there are potential risks that land acquisition may delay construction 
activities or that resettlement implementation may not fully restore all livelihoods. These risks 
have been minimized or will be mitigated by a carefully prepared detailed implementation plan, 
compensation standards, budget and schedule, which are managed by the Project Company’s 
land acquisition and resettlement department and monitored by an independent institute. Given 
that, in addition to the EA, various municipal agencies such as the public security bureau and 
environmental  protection  bureau  are  involved  in  implementing  the  Project,  interagency 
coordination may not be carried out as envisaged. To mitigate this risk, a leading group chaired 
by the mayor and comprising senior officials of the local government has been established 
(para.16).

political, economic, and cultural center, while the satellite towns have local industries, building

D.  Road Safety 
 
4.  Road  safety  is  a  serious  issue  in  Xi’an.  In  2002,  the  municipality  reported  4,114 
accidents (58.6 per 100,000 people), 508 fatalities (7.2 per 100,000 people), and 3,214 injuries 
(45.8 per 100,000 people). The Xi’an accident fatality rate is lower than the national average of 
8.3 per 100,000 people. A Road Safety Council was established to improve investigation of and 
reporting procedures for road accidents so as to devise strategies and policies to reduce road 
accidents,  and  to  improve  coordination  among  concerned  agencies.  The  function  and

Implementing a comprehensive  road safety audit program  as part of the proposed Project 
should help reduce the number and severity of road accidents in the urban area of Xi’an. 
 
5.  The  problem  of  road  safety  and  responsibility  for  improving  do  not  rest  solely  on 
government departments. Road safety is a shared responsibility among stakeholders, central, 
provincial and local governments; education and enforcement authorities; health care providers; 
the media; the insurance industry; community groups and individuals who use or are affected by 
the road system.  An appropriate road safety strategy will include developing safer attitudes, 
skills, and behavior among users of the road system; improving the safety of roads, the road 
environment,  and  traffic  management;  enhancing  the  safety  of  vehicles  and  improving 
operational standards; and achieving greater community and industry awareness and ownership 
of, and participation in road safety. These dimensions are included in the proposed Project. 
 
E.  Vehicle Emissions Control 
 
6.  Air quality in most cities is poor and vehicle emissions pose health threats to the urban 
population. Congestion and inadequate traffic management make emissions worse. With rapid 
population growth in PRC cities and increasing vehicle ownership, air pollution will worsen if 
mitigation measures are not taken. Xi’an is no exception. 
 
7.  Although the transport sector contributes to pollutants in the overall air shed of Xi’an, it is 
difficult to tell how much is attributable to fixed versus mobile sources of pollution. Air pollution is 
not monitored or predicted based on fixed or mobile sources of pollutants. Predictive models do 
not consider future vehicular technologies, average travel speeds, and length of travel. The 
models  are  usually  based  on  current  technologies  and  established  fuel  sources.  A  more 
effective air quality management policy must be developed over the immediate and longer term. 
 
8.  Regulating  vehicle  emissions  is  the  responsibility  of  local  environmental  protection 
bureaus in cooperation with the traffic division of the public security bureaus.1 The Public 
Security Bureau and Environmental Protection Bureau in Xi’an share responsibility for air quality 
control, inspection and maintenance, annual vehicle testing centers, and enforcement.  
 
F.  Public Transport 
 
9.  In Xi’an, public transport, including local and long-distance buses and taxies, is governed 
by the Xi’an Municipal Transport Bureau. There are 16 providers of local bus transport services. 
Most bus transport is provided by the Xi’an Public Transport Company, which operates 88% of 
the bus routes. Established in 1979, it is a state-owned enterprise that operates 147 bus routes 
with a total length of 2,769 km and owns 2,955 buses. It has 13 operational units (including 8 
subcompanies and other 5 operational units) with 9,369 employees, and fixed asset of CNY602 
million.

unit of the Xi’an Public Transport Company has its own bus depot and maintenance plant. In the 
last few years, the bus fleet has rapidly increased. However, the number and capacity of bus

URBAN TRANSPORT IMPROVEMENT 
 
1.  The Project comprises five urban transport initiatives: (i) traffic management and road 
safety, (ii) vehicle emission control, (iii) road maintenance, (iv) urban transport planning, and (v)

A.  Traffic Management and Road Safety 
 
1.  Area Traffic Control Center and Traffic Signals 
   
2.  The Project will expand the current small traffic signal system of the Public Security 
Bureau (PSB) to include 110 additional signalized intersections. The new system will include a 
fully equipped Area Traffic Control (ATC) Center with a capacity to handle over 250 signalized 
intersections. The center will be located in a newly built Traffic Management and Signal Control 
complex.  The  new  system  will  enhance  road  traffic  flow,  increase  vehicle  speed,  reduce 
intersection delay, and improve road safety on the urban roads in Xi'an. To implement the new 
ATC system, the PSB will (i) review existing traffic signal deployment and its application; (ii) 
assess the benefits and weakness of the existing signalized system including intersection 
channelization, signal phasing and timing, and vehicle and pedestrian delays; (iii) identify the 
location  of  new  and  potential  ATC  intersections;  (iv)  collect  traffic  data  at  the  new  ATC 
intersections; (v) carry out a pilot study of a selected number of the new ATC intersections in a 
selected district to demonstrate the benefits and effectiveness of ATC system development; (vi) 
evaluate the potential development and expansion of an ATC system to cover all intersections in 
Xi’an; (vii) assess the costs and benefits based on a study analyzing the situation before and 
after implementation of the ATC system, and evaluation of car drivers/passengers, bus riders, 
cyclists, and pedestrians; and (viii) prepare the implementation and procurement program for 
the ATC system.  
 
3.  The Project will improve relevant intersections, considering the following issues: (i) 
improve  staff  capability  for  applying  recognized  technical  packages  for  signalized  and 
nonsignalized intersection analysis; and (ii) prepare a comprehensive program to collect traffic 
data, and carry out regular intersection analysis and monitoring. 
 
2.  Road Safety Audit Program 
 
4.  Implementing an effective road safety audit program is an efficient way to improve road 
safety conditions and to reduce the number and severity of accidents. A road safety audit is a 
formal examination of existing or future road conditions, which interacts with road users. An 
independent,  qualified  examiner  reports  on  the  project's  accident  potential  and  safety 
performance. A road safety audit considers all road users, including various pedestrian groups, 
cyclists,  motorcyclists,  and  operators  of  heavy  vehicles.  It  relies  heavily  on  established 
guidelines and standards, and also on the ability of the auditor to recognize a potentially 
hazardous combination of elements, which may not be covered by specific guidelines. The main 
reason for conducting road safety audits is to prevent road accidents by identifying potential 
safety problems that may require corrective action. Road safety audits seek to ensure that, as 
far as practicable, road and traffic schemes are safe and fit for the purpose for which they are 
intended. The project roads will be subject to road safety audit during the design stage and prior 
to opening. The Project will also include a comprehensive road safety audit program across 
Xi’an by ensuring that (i) elements that could cause accidents  (e.g., road furniture near the 
edge of traffic lanes) are not present in the road network; (ii) elements that could reduce the risk 
of road accidents (e.g., anti-skid surfacing) are included in the operational road network; and (iii) 
elements that reduce the severity of road accidents  (e.g., accident barriers) are included in the 
overall road network.

7.  There are only seven compressed natural gas (CNG) stations in Xi'an; two are used

construction  of  10  new  CNG  stations,  which  will  include  civil/foundation  works,  piping,

2.  Mobile Emission Inspection System 
 
8.  Only the Environment Protection Bureau has the capacity to carry out roadside emission 
inspection of vehicles at two locations at a time. To facilitate better emission control on road

mobile emission inspection vehicle, and some inspection units.  
 
3.   Action Plan  
 
9.  With the help of consultants, a comprehensive quality management and vehicle emission 
control action plan will be prepared under the Project. The plan will relate to existing and future 
land use and development of traffic zones. Existing and planned transport infrastructure will be 
considered in applying the plan.   
 
C.  Road Maintenance 
 
10.  Many roads in the urban areas of Xi’an municipality are old and require maintenance. 
Existing road maintenance equipment is inadequate to maintain the urban road network in 
acceptable condition. Better maintenance is needed to reduce road accidents and to facilitate 
smoother traffic operations. The Project will finance equipment to implement more effective road 
maintenance programs for all roads in the urban area, and will finance the maintenance of 
selected  urban  roads,  including  improvement  of  pedestrian  movements  and  nonmotorized 
transport lanes.  
 
D.  Urban Transport Planning 
 
11.  Because future urban transport planning and design work depends on reliable traffic 
forecasts, a comprehensive traffic forecasting and planning model should be developed for Xi'an 
municipality. The existing model developed by Chang'an University needs improvement to better 
predict future traffic volumes on urban roads by different transport modes. A comprehensive 
traffic forecasting and planning model will be developed. The Xi'an municipal government will 
undertake the following actions:

1.  The Project, comprising the 71-kilometer (km) ring road and 16-km of connector roads in 
Xi’an municipality will be implemented in about 4 years. The economic analysis covers 20 years 
of operation. Without the Project, traffic will use the existing urban road network, which will soon 
be congested and expensive to maintain because of the rapidly increasing traffic. With the 
Project, congestion on the existing roads will be reduced, and traffic on both project roads and 
existing roads will benefit from faster, cheaper, and safer travel.  
 
A.  Valuation of Costs and Benefits

wages paid to unskilled labor, but not on wages for skilled labor since there was no surplus of 
skilled workers. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.67 was used to convert the financial wage rate 
to an economic opportunity cost of labor.

B.  Least-Cost Analysis 
 
6.  The primary objective of the project road is to provide adequate capacity in the selected 
corridors up to the design year. The designs are consistent with a reasonable quality of service, 
given the forecast peak-hour traffic volumes. The corridors themselves were chosen to accord 
with the land use plan of the Xi’an municipality. The planners considered directly serving areas 
north of the orbital road by aligning the northern section of the third ring road (TRR) accordingly. 
This option was dropped on cost grounds. Aligning the southern section of the TRR to the south 
of the orbital road was not considered necessary for land use planning. The northern and 
southern sections along the orbital road are least-cost solutions to provide the required increase 
in corridor capacity. 
 
7.  Both  the eastern and western sections of the TRR are on new alignments. These 
alignments were selected primarily to promote new development corridors for the city, to ease 
the development pressure on the increasingly congested central areas. The alternative options 
to provide additional capacity in the eastern and western corridors—widening the eastern and 
western sections of the orbital road or constructing an elevated road on top of the second ring 
road—would both forgo the development benefits and result in the large area between the 
orbital road and the second ring road not being adequately served. An elevated road on the 
second ring road would be very expensive because some sections are over watercourses.

separately from the main road component. First, for the area traffic control subcomponent, 
which  provides  equipment  for  the  control  center  and  controlled  traffic  signals  at  110

separately. Time  savings  would  amount  to  CNY138 million comprising CNY117 million to

and a 1-year delay in completion  do not affect economic  viability. Combinations of adverse

maintain its economic viability under those scenarios.

Direct impacts will be derived from construction employment opportunities, savings in travel 
time, and the potential for vehicle cost savings in passenger transport (buses) to be passed on 
to passengers. The Project will benefit the local poor and migrant workers by hiring unskilled 
and semiskilled labor for construction activities. It has been observed that most of the job 
opportunities in other road construction projects in and around Xi’an go to the poor since the 
work is arduous and relatively low paying compared with other opportunities in the city. On-the-

result from the third ring road (TRR) and induced urbanization. Congestion on the first and

areas. The poor will benefit from trickle down effects from improvements in the local economy.

opportunities to diversify income. Household poverty and vulnerability will be reduced with 
multiple income earners and more than one source of income.  Survey data shows that rural 
households with incomes over and above that derived solely from agricultural production are 
better off than households that rely solely on farming (cropping or livestock).

B.  Resettlement Principles and Compensation 
 
3.  Land acquisition is governed by the 1998 Land Administration Law of the People’s 
Republic of China, the 1999 Methods of Execution of the Land Administration Law in Shaanxi, 
and the 2003  Management Regulations of Xi’an Urban Building Removal. Resettlement will 
follow ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and Social Protection Strategy, as well as the 
local resettlement practices for similar projects in Xi’an. The resettlement plan (RP) addresses 
losses and impacts on different groups, businesses, and structures. Based on the inventory of 
losses, an entitlement matrix was developed, which recognizes all types of affected persons 
(AP) and their losses, irrespective of ownership or registration (Table A15.2). Losses suffered 
by AP have been categorized as land loss, structure loss, land attachment loss, business/salary 
loss, and crop loss. 
 
4.  The main objective of the RP is to restore and improve the economic condition of the 
APs,  particularly  vulnerable  groups.  Measures  such  as  a  transitional  allowance  for  lost 
livelihood, business/economic rehabilitation support, and training for livelihoods were adopted. 
Economic  rehabilitation  will  be  partly  supported  by  employment  and  income  generation 
opportunities related to project construction works.

C.  Stakeholder Participation, Disclosure of RP, and Grievances 
 
5.  Since the Project will have significant impacts, community views were sought through 
consultation meetings. Between July 2002 and February 2003, 33 focus group discussions were 
conducted, 1,550 households in 22 affected villages were surveyed, and owners of 20 affected 
enterprises were interviewed. From April to June 2003, all affected villages and enterprises 
were investigated and consulted, and seriously affected villages formulated initial rehabilitation 
plans. In July 2003, 5,000 copies of a resettlement information booklet were distributed to all 
affected  villages,  households,  and  enterprises.  In  August,  the  approved  compensation 
standards and road alignment were announced to the local people. At various stages of project 
planning,  APs  were  informed  of,  and  consulted  about,  the  likely  impacts  of  the  Project. 
Stakeholders consulted included (i) heads of households/business units to be affected; (ii) 
village heads and villagers’ representatives; (iii) local government agencies and departments; 
and (iv) women, the poor, and other vulnerable groups.  More intensive consultations were 
undertaken to formulate village rehabilitation plans for the most seriously affected villages. The 
consultations will continue throughout project implementation.  
 
6.  The RP prepared by the Xi’an Municipal Third Ring Road Construction and Development 
Company (Project Company) was discussed with  local government agencies to understand 
local and Asian Development Bank (ADB) policies, compensation standards, and resettlement 
strategy. Public consultation meetings held in each affected district verified local support for the 
Project. Regarding land acquisition and resettlement, there were concerns about adjusting the 
road alignment, improved compensation standards, resettlement  options, and entitlements. 
Once the final design is approved, there will be a detailed measurement survey of the alignment 
and  compensation  agreements  will  be  signed  with  all  affected  villages,  households,  and 
enterprises.  
 
D.   Resettlement Site Development and Rehabilitation Assistance 
 
7.  Resettlement site selection  was considered with the income restoration plans. There 
were three options in selecting residential resettlement sites: (i) for areas where only several 
households are involved in house relocation (light impact), the new housing sites  can be 
selected in the same village/community; (ii) for a village with  more households involved in 
relocation, but with enough land for their livelihoods (intermediate impact), a site with existing or 
new apartment buildings  can be selected, considering farmers’ production and operational 
convenience;  or  (iii)  for  a  village  with  a  serious  relocation  impact,  a  separate  village 
rehabilitation plan was formulated, for which final site selection will be determined once the 
project feasibility study is approved. For the relocated enterprises, new sites will be planned by 
the Xi’an Municipal Planning Commission. Each enterprise will be responsible for reemploying 
staff and contract workers, and will be assisted with subsidies where necessary. 
 
8.  There  will  be  few  opportunities  for  agricultural  development  because  urbanization 
pressure in the project area is already strong, except in places such a Chang’An ancient city 
where investment will be made for vegetable gardening and animal husbandry. Fortunately, 
commercial  and  industrial  opportunities  near  the  new  ring  road  will  improve  significantly. 
Proposed income rehabilitation measures are as follows: (i) provide employment opportunities 
in new commercial and industrial enterprises, (ii) establish collective  enterprises, (iii) open 
private shops and businesses, (iv) rent land and housing, and (v) provide subsidies and social 
security system for vulnerable groups and poor households. Within each category, detailed 
needs for farmers to expand their working skills will be identified, and relevant training will be 
planned. For vulnerable groups, the Project will provide a special social assistance fund to help 
each household restore its livelihood.
